cKaiQHPZtYEumXr6WeEYHw.text: Went last night with 3 friends and had a brilliant time as well as brilliant food. Booked table well over a week in advance and glad I did that. Booking is recommended here as the restaurant is very popular. Seating is a bit crowded but atmosphere is lively and worth the small discomfort. Bread (a soft, highly leavened, rustic type) was served with garlic mayo which was unusual and tasty. The tapas dishes were very tasty and varied. Good selection of vegetarian options (over a dozen) and they were very, very flavoursome and tasty!! Recommended. We particularly enjoyed the aubergines and chick peas dish. Really, really good.

csP8LXHdfClhRpo7NVZ4ag.text: Conveniently located near the Park Lane Sheraton, but if you are traveling alone on business, think twice..I've lived in Madrid, so I get the social aspect of Spanish dining. But, the manager here makes it very clear he could care less about your business. No tables, no split menus items, sit at the bar of find somewhere else to dine. Poor, considering personal experience other major business locations around the globe.Food is ok, but the manager should recognize that many business people travel through this area -  many of whom know when they clearly are seen as turn-over in advance of the next larger party.I'll think of other spots the next time I am here in the next month with my wife and family.

G883eZGPIKJ0EdrIye6GfA.text: Extremely poor service, grumpy waiters, food was at best mediocre.  Tasted like they used ketchup to flavour the dishes.  Wine was overpriced.  Don't bother.

SNEAxzL_6A6PJny0dnPcWw.text: As other reviewers have also noted, you do generally need to reserve a table in advance, especially if you are a big group. Alternatively, make sure you arrive early. A busy restaurant is the sign of a good restaurant, and I do love this restaurant! It has an amazing atmosphere, an awesome menu and great food, super friendly and helpful waiting staff and an overall wonderful ambiance. Totally recommend El Pirata for an authentic Spanish dining experience.

_EwGczf9kKe0mWOiCK9fMw.text: Was in London on the way to Italy and our hotel recommended El Pirata.  It was quite busy so we actually sat at the bar but had a great time.  Some great dishes and awesome sangria.  The bartender chatted us up quite a bit which was great.  Highly recommended!

N8zjty6KcHRtfFMKz_ALcA.text: 8 of us went here last Thursday - I booked the table 24 hours beforehand.It's not easy to get a booking for eight late on in a decent restaurant in London - let alone a great table.But this place exceeded my expectations - proper tapas menu, good price, buzzing atmosphere but you could still have a conversation with people around the table, and to top it all - service with a genuine smile and passion for what they do.I almost thought I was back in Spain........

XJIT3QcJUPFmkNnZ-8QlIA.text: This is a fantastic Spanish restaurant! You may as well be in Barcelona. Brilliant seafood, amazing meats and I really loved their grilled Asparagus with a heavenly sauce. Cant recommend this place enough.

Z1SpjslXR2AUtcbgemZlkQ.text: Went there with 3 friends. We were seated downstairs, which is slightly hall-y when empty, but the place quickly filled. Tapas were traditional, no fuss, non-fusion, just proper Spanish. Pulpo a la gallega top notch, loved the mini eels, nice garlicky prawns, tasty chicken al ajillo. Wine list good value, I find, with some decent choices in the 20-25£ range. Only miss out to a complete 5* were the potatoes, which were dry and tasteless. Stick to the meats, seafood, and vegetables. Excellent choice, and we left at £30 per head, including coffees and a shared dessert. Nice detail: a list of recommended years for Spanish red wines on the back of the business card. There you go.

2fyGJih_A7OZgzLih7PXkA.text: This is one of my favorite restaurants in London, the other being Scalni's. The tapas selection is right on and they have all of my favorites - piquillo peppers stuffed with russian salad, croquetas de pollo, spanish omelette with potatoes & onions, patatas bravas, and pitchers of the best red sangria! Excellent service and fun atmosphere!

vNg-OxXrIx4MG0GSe7vaTA.text: My wife and I love El Pirata.  We always eat there our 1st night in London and our last night.  The prices are good, the food is great. The service is very good also.  The key is to sit upstairs, drink lots of Sangria and save room for desert.

TwWHS7xKlOY4ijxj2xb08g.text: Okay, it's a bit dingy and loud but the food is great and the wine list affordable and extensive. I've been going here for years and they've never let me down. Although I'd love to see them reinstate the salmon croquettes! Please order them, so we might get it back on the menu. Try the baby eels - it's not as adventurous as it sounds; they are soft and creamy. Btw, who's the joker who classified this place as Greek? This place is more Spanish than Penelope Cruz (before Hollywood discovered her, that is).

1OT3h_jrzsHpa-2X-lslaw.text: Great find in the neighborhood of Mayfair. Delicious, ample servings of authentic tapas in a quaint setting where every table feels private. Order the mushrooms, cheese plate with quince and the seafood paella is incredible. We will be back!

MilWbj2y2E-nLaFKWaw1CA.text: Ok, so just back from dinner there.  Spanish, sure, but don't keep your expectations too high for what you'd expect in Spain.  The wine list is scattered with typical wines from Spain, and they DO cover all the regions, but with wines you'd find in a decent wine store: nothing really exquisite.  I had a 2001 Muga Gran Reserva £89. Ok, not a great price but a good solid Rioja.  Then had the peppers and Jamon Serrano for appetizers.  Tough to screw up so it was good.  Then came the main order.. steak.  I ordered rare and to emphasize it I even said "rojo" or red in spanish to make sure the Brazilian waiter got the order right.  Even the guy sitting next to me at the bar heard me say "walk the cow by and I'll take a bite out of it" to emphasize that I meant RARE.   The steak came out 30 minutes later well done. Oy!  Then to make up for it the manager said he'd buy dessert and Muscatel.   On the bill was the Muscatel....  I know enough Spanish to know he told our waiter to give us both.. but somehow the manager rescinded the free Muscatel by the end of the evening as I asked him about it AFTER paying.  "Oh I just told him to give you the free dessert" FYI, I didn't order the Muscatel.... and wouldn't have.  So... BE CAREFUL if you go there.

qInNRTmUJ_un5I8I6PZCJA.text: One of the best tapas restaurant outside Spain. Ask the waiter to just come up with dishes to surprise you and sit back to eat. What could be more fun and relaxing. Excellent food and good wine in a nice environment. Yet another of my favorites, of which I have a few...

z-PbUpPYR-A3kO25uW7x0w.text: Really like this tapas restaurant, the food is very good, and great if you are in a group as I always tend to over-order! Upstairs only has a few tables but there is much more seating downstairs. Get there early for lunch or book ahead as it is very popular. Some tables outside in the summer but they go quick.

CIvTLm5P4dnnQ2bA-r065w.text: Very attentive service and the food was top notch. We ordered around 8 different plates of tapas and they all arrived at roughly the same time and was piping hot. Good selection of wines on the menu and if you can get there early enough or request it you can get a table outside which is a bonus during the summer.  They also have a set introduction to Tapas menu which although I didn't try did have my slightly intrigued so another visit may be in order

50Gxy-3-05WedtaUUEyYFA.text: My coworker told me I had to come here for the food...well the food was decent, okay tapas, great paella but AWESOME drinks! Come here for their drinks! This was a great meal to splurge on and finish off a week long trip to London.

photos.caption: Photo of El Pirata - Mayfair, London, United Kingdom
Photo of El Pirata - Mayfair, London, United Kingdom
Photo of El Pirata - Mayfair, London, United Kingdom

dtwqS9wnCsbY0eM35l0-rA.text: My friend and I enjoyed this place.  Staff was very attentive and helpful.  Inside is small but they fit us in nicely.   dessert choice was a little lacking in my opinion but everything else was good.

TXOxIjy9s0aJ8yGlOBNo3g.text: This was a yelp suggestion after I tried looking for Tapas Bars somewhere near Hyde Park Corner. The tapas bar located in Mayfair is a less than 5 minute walk near the Hard Rock Cafe.While the food is not extraordinary, there is a rather appealing energy that makes up for it. A lot of the food was fried and generously drenched in oil. The squid and the prawns were both fresh but were floating in oil. The baby eels were delicious but again, too much oil.The service is well above average however, with friendly and patient waiters offering adequate help to supplement your thoughts on the menu. Our waitress even rightly told us that we might be over-ordering which we found out to our shock that we much more than over ordered. I would probably come back to try out some of the vegetarian tapas just to make sure I didn't miss something, but definitely not something that would come to my mind when recommending a tapas bar.

X2WRrT7a-gjFC0h7GbUivw.text: One of my long time favourite restaurants in London.  The food and wine are good and it has a good atmosphere.  It also has a bar area where I like to eat at when I am by myself.

Yy1gC4n52ZJ4_MTp8kmm8Q.text: It was Friday, 930pm, and we were in Mayfair looking for a place to have a last minute birthday meal (large group of 3). We stumbled across a very busy El Pirata and thought we would give it a try.  The waiter told us it would be at least a 45 mins wait for a table, but we could sit and eat at the bar straight away (which is what you would do in Spain so it didn't bother us).The service staff were friendly and prompt enough considering it was a full house. I was quite surprised at the reasonable prices considering the location. We ordered some cocktails and set menu 2, once the food started to arrive we switched to Sangria. The sangria was fine, nothing special, but definitely drinkable.Food:  The food was very tasty. The tapas frias (cold) was fine, nice selection of cured meats, seafood and salad. The monk fish medallions, prawns and calamares, all tasted fresh, not over cooked, nor swimming in oil.  I particularly enjoyed the peppers stuffed with hake mousse.The steak medallions and lamb cutlets were tasty and cooked well, the potato omelet was fine, by this stage I was filling up. I didn't care much for the chicken wings, but that just personal taste.The atmosphere in the restaurant was buzzing, we got talking to the groups sitting both sides of us at the bar. I noticed one of them eating something that looked amazing. They said it was baby eels, I had to give it a try.  1 x  "Gulas con patatas asadas"  please (baby eels in olive oil, garlic, dried hot chili peppers & roasted potatoes). This was my favourite dish of the evening, very tasty (if you like garlic), my wife couldn't bring herself to try them as some appeared to be still swimming in the oil (fresh??).The meal came to about £40 per person, which included a lot of food, cocktails and multiple jugs of sangria, not bad in my opinion. I would quite happily recommend giving El Pirata a try if you are in the area. Food was good and reasonably priced, and the service was friendly.

WFC4D6-M_n44Y9F-DdOWdQ.text: What a great night.  We had a group of 6 and were given a secluded table that really added to our evening.  Wine, food, service all excellent.  I have been here a few times over the past 10 years and even though this was my first visit in 2 years I felt like a weekly regular with how warmly we were treated.

S5xMF8DaEPR26WaX4UCbCg.text: No shortage of tapas places in London, and either you walk  out broke or you walk out hungry and broke. This place breaks nothing, and good god it tastes fantastic. Actually I went to Madrid right after London, so within reason I can positively state that this tapas place would hold it's own against most tapas bars in Madrid.The only bit that was a bit annoying was just how long it took to get a table. We sat at the bar for an hour before being approached by a very hurried fellow, who then gave us a table sort of squished between the kitchen traffic and the bar traffic. Absolutely no elbow space to speak off.There were the four of us, so we got a load of different things. No meat on this occasion, and we still had more than enough options. So for vegetarians and epicureans, I'd say this is a good bet. They have a decent selection of wines, and some are quite reasonable as well.

1OqIefRky80Oic9I3r4qpw.text: Mrs and I just got back to the hotel from this place, just down the block.  I have to agree with Bruce B. of San Francisco on this one when he says "nothing good".  I don't get to London often enough to recommend a better tapas place, but this one is not worth anyone's time.We were seated upstairs right away, and our young waiter was pleasant enough (when he was around at all).  I asked him if the fried calamari was crisp, that was important to me or I'd rather not order it at all.  He assured me it was very crisp.  Well, it had a mushy, tasteless coating, I ate one or two of the rings, and couldn't force myself to eat any more of that tasteless dish.  I simply left the almost full plate on the table, and when he came by he asked me if it was OK, and I politely told him that a wet, bready coating was not what I thought I was going to get.  The calamari was on my bill at the end of the meal, and I never said a word, as I would never go back to this place anyway.A sliced pork appetizer was fairly tasty, but at 9.75 GBP for 4 tiny slices of meat, I felt a bit robbed.  A glass of sangria was ridiculously sweet, and I'm certain there was no alcohol anywhere in that glass.  We asked for bread, which had no distinguishable crust, was soft and tasteless, and, be forewarned, though not mentioned anywhere on the menu, they will charge you 1.15 GBP per person at the table, even when a single small basket is all that is brought.My wife thought her sliced beef was OK, a plate of potatoes was completely tasteless and undercooked - this was certainly one of the worst meals we have ever had in London.  While obviously my thoughts on this place seem to be a minority view, which is fine, I just have to say that 67 GBP for one of the worst meals I have ever had in London makes for a place that I would never return to (something I reported to our concierge, even though he had not recommended it).

a5e4lvdR1KfKgp1_S05TOw.text: Maybe I came in with low expectations since I just came from Barcelona and this restaurant is in a place not know for culinary expertise but this was a very good meal. Service was friendly and the food was very good. The bartender made an excellent calimocho...though it is a very easy drink to make.

AFZKqwLPu4bNILBIUBI5Pg.text: Nothing extraordinary but still pretty good tapas.  My only complaint is the watered down sangria

XJKTDeo5kCunumtV0WSr6A.text: Was in the area for a very brief trip and after having unsuccessfully tried to find food at some of the surrounding pubs (do all their kitchens close by 8?), I decided to pop my head into El Pirata. It was quite busy and as such I seated myself at the bar. I started off with an affordable glass of red wine, the name of which I can't recall (most likely do to the continuation of merriment later into evening). The service was great, and I left most of the tapas decision making up to the bartender. Of the tapas I do recall, the more notable and tasty ones were the montaditos de jamón serrano (toasted bread with olive oil and fresh tomatoes topped with cured ham) and the langostinos al chef (grilled king prawns in a sauce of tomato, garlic & white wine).The atmosphere was lively, especially for a Wednesday. And while the food wasn't exemplary, it was tasty and filling. El Pirata seems like it would be a fun place to explore with a group of friends; that is after all what tapas are best for.

gtAw5S9hCmdu4HXcmpokpQ.text: Really average. Nothing bad, but nothing good either. The prices are lower then the rest of the area though.  Decent value.  Our hotel was only a few blocks away, so this was convenient.  Otherwise, I wouldn't go out of the way for this.

3uPU9tiuYHgn4yoHuPnAdw.text: The food was nice. One bottle of wine, two glasses of water, six plates and a plate of ham costed 160 pounds. I think it's expensive,They cooked tapas really nicely thought...

MrJHor10aSCeX5q-uWq3eg.text: Delicious food at very reasonable prices (especially given it's in Mayfair!). Fantastic service and a great atmosphere. Great date venue - lively but intimate at the same time. Come back here whenever I am in London!

rQyXlrlCLcFCieLTR7dDOA.text: This another hidden mayfair gem in the sheppards market area. Memories of good friends, banter and great tapas.heading here you must explore the tiny streets its located in. Downstairs is good for parties!

QwtMZVCpf0E80xZ-8QcpjQ.text: Don't let its simple store front look fool you. Escorted to the basement was at first a put-off. But the excellent service and menu softened me. What a great experience. And food was outstanding.

SX-Yuloc5sp7WJw73q7bBA.text: Very authentic and tasty tapas!  Also, one of the most reasonably priced restaurants options you can find in this area of London.  The place is very busy and bustling (and can be a bit loud) but service is fast.  Good selection of Spanish wines from inexpensive to high end.

iPBgBrWCt0_BBDkXJlbvMw.text: Really good Tapas, really good beer, really good wine, really good service. One of my favourite Restaraunts.

N35-W1cTZmFPxVDYA8livQ.text: walked in, several waiters passed by while avoiding eye contact, and there is no host to greet you and make you feel welcome. got a "how dare you" look from a flagged down waiter once I indicated I had no reservation. got seated next to toilets and started enjoying lavatory smells everytime door swung open. after a long period of inattention, I had to walk up a flight of stairs to flag a waiter and ask to be reseated. I figured there should be no problem, since there were plenty of empty tables available everywhere, and it was quite past prime dinner time. after checking with El Hefe (oh there he is, hiding in the back, instead of greeting customers, up front, and making us feel welcome), he received a quick headshake, and then had to profusely apologize to us about not being able to reseat us. newsflash: just because a celebrity had a good time here, once, it doesn't mean the next batch of your doorwalking revenue will. instead walked over to Prezzo kiddy corner away, and left my money for far better service and dining experience. net-net: won't be back, despite it being around the corner from our hotel.

H6u_xoDxZRKz-yhLyNsW0A.text: First tapas experience. Quite pleased! Ordered the calamari and chicken with chorizo skewers along with fresh bread for dinner. Finished it off with crema Catalina for dessert. Very declicious!

7cEubNmxlAnGii2laVAFkA.text: I like Spanish food and tapas, as much as any pescatarian part time veggie can like Spanish food and tapas. El Pirata is a nice little gem in Mayfair which is a bit unusual because generally you can only find insanely upscale restaurants in this area. It's impressive how many tapas options El Pirata has for you, and we were here with a couple so we tried a lot of different things. The one that stood out was langostinos al chef- a delightful dish of grilled king prawns with tomato, garlic and white wine. They were indeed delicious. The place is A-Ok, nothing more for me. The reason being is that the prices are very high for a lot of the food they are presenting, and although they offer a lot of dishes, not all are amazing. We tried 11 different dishes, and the one that I remember and really enjoyed was the langostinos al chef. The others were fine, but wouldn't bring me back.

photos.caption: Photo of El Pirata - Mayfair, London, United Kingdom. Profitaroles
Photo of El Pirata - Mayfair, London, United Kingdom. Chocolate crepe
Photo of El Pirata - Mayfair, London, United Kingdom. arroz negro

B7vXZ55pNchlMjat2DfVgg.text: The feeling of Spanish authenticity is everywhere in El Pirata and it feels like you are sitting in Spain. I visited on my own when in London and was looking forward to the meal from the moment I walked through the door. The service was excellent, and the waiter helped my build a dinner that matched my appetite. I started with pan con tomate, and this was as good as I've had. I paired this with padron green peppers from Galicia and jamón serrano for the perfect start to the meal.For main course, I opted for a trio that felt like they would compliment each other. They absolutely did - the chuletitas de cordero, carrillera and uevos rotos especiales were made for each other! Each was cooked with skill and care. I didn't want the mains to end, as I tucked into each of these. The carrillera was just perfect, as it carried all of the flavours - it makes me smile just writing about it now.To finish I went for the repe de chocolate, which is a pancake filled with chocolate sauce, flaked almonds & served with vanilla ice cream. It tasted as good as it sounds, and I would come back to El Pirata for this alone. I recommend the restaurant for anyone. From the service to the décor and on to the food, it was a delight in every single way. If you ever near Mayfair, then this is worth visiting.

photos.caption: Photo of El Pirata - Mayfair, London, United Kingdom
Photo of El Pirata - Mayfair, London, United Kingdom
Photo of El Pirata - Mayfair, London, United Kingdom

QiNg-sIa8eRq-YYyt70lFA.text: Great food and service.. loved the tapas and food!!! If you go to London don't miss out on going there

hsNG3RrOstshnwu41UHlFQ.text: One of my favorites in London-never miss an opportunity to have dinner here. Great for groups, couples, whatever! If your at the Sheraton Park Lane it's just off the back of the hotel in an alley so very convenient.Great prices and a very nice wine selection!!

ywjwNHRwQzl8pMEnVKhBFg.text: Solid tapas in an area lacking good options! There was a meatball dish with a sauce that we fought over finishing with our bread. Speaking of the bread, it's plentiful and kept the 3 kids we were with occupied when they were bored with trying new things. You heard that right, we brought 3 kids here! They did a great job accommodating us, my only complaint being our server disappeared at the end of the meal and we ended up waiting almost 30 minutes just to pay our tab. Kids were getting unmanageable and it was a bit of a sad way to end an otherwise pleasant meal. The sampling menu was enough to feed 2 adults with a small appetite. One each would be good if you're more hungry. Try to sit downstairs if you can, the alcoves are unique!

61QzHpU9rqIcMAKWBmeFmg.text: Whenever my coworkers and I hold meetings in London, we make El Pirata one of the dinner spots.  They serve tapas of course, and has two set menus to choose from with about a dozen dishes each.  In addition they have individual appetizers and entrees too.  Our party of six had an excellent dinner here, with good wine and food.  Service was great in the beginning but then was a bit slower midway through the meal.  Some memorable dishes were:- Spanish Jamon - similar to Italian prosciutto.  Absolutely addictive.- The free bread has this amazing, creamy garlic mayo that was full of flavor.- Both the braised baby lamb shanks (BTW they were huge with lots of meat) and grilled lamb chops were cooked perfectly.- Octopus was tender and had a very spicy kick.  One of my coworkers never had octopus but this probably made him a fan.Probably only minor disappointment was the pork belly - it had a real hard, crispy and thick skin but could probably use some more cooking time.  Dessert options were also limited - mostly Creme brûlée, flans, and rice puddings.Would definitely recommend this restaurant - you get to sample lots of different dishes and get full by a nibble at a time.

photos.caption: Photo of El Pirata - Mayfair, London, United Kingdom. Baby Lamb Shank.
Photo of El Pirata - Mayfair, London, United Kingdom. Tonight's menu.  We mostly got Set 2 but our waiter threw in a few specials on top.

SNKrlPdZany_7Dv2cATvlg.text: Our seafood Paella was a little dry, the Padron peppers were great. The Pan Con Tomate was excellent, probably better than the one I had in Madrid or Barcelona. The Pulpo was mediocre, In fact, I was discouraged with the wooden plate they used to plate the dish, because it soaked most of the flavorings and olive oil, and the octopus was more rubbery in texture than it should have been . The place was also too compactly seated. I was literally in elbow to elbow with the next Guest behind me who was overly gesturing with his friend while conversing. There isn't that much option in this particular block, and learning from this, I will organize my time better to plan for Piccadilly Circus area instead, or better yet just head down to Hard Rock Cafe which is a block away---definitely not a place i would go back to again. I also noticed, that most of the Guests who were of Asian Heritage like I am were seated in the underground level...  maybe a coincidence tonight(??)... ---Just stating my observation. When we finished our dinner, on our way out, there were no Asians in the upper level. It was an odd atmosphere.

nLZKFG2_RUX-IZg7_bi6YQ.text: After checking out of the Park Lane but before heading to Paddington to catch the H.E., I suddenly realized I had not eaten anything all day and it was already 2pm. Knowing I was headed to one of the many awful LHR hotels, I figured it's best to eat in the city, and all I had to do was look up and see the sign on El Pirata.I might have well have taken the 2.5 hour flight to Madrid, because this was authentically Spanish, down to the service staff with whom I enjoyed a great conversation while polishing up my rusty español.This was a standard snack type meal - chorizo in red wine sauce, grilled calamari, a tortilla de patatas, and of course, a vino tinto. Some bread and garlic aioli was served as well.With the misty afternoon, my experience at el Pirata was a comforting meal in so many ways -- the flavor, the wine, and discussion about Spain with the staff.I'm not entirely up on the Spanish dining scene in London, but having lived in Spain for a year, I can very much tell you that this place is the real deal and serves up some fantastic flavors that, if you closed your eyes, would have you thinking you're on the Iberian peninsula.

-Vz8oyHqqJfIGysZzwCKqg.text: Good location with few options in the immediate area. Good atmosphere upstairs pretty dull downstairsFood is very average. Similar to what you'd get at a truck stop/ motorway service station  in Spain. Nothing memorable of the 8 we tried and small portions even though is tapas. Mark up on wine is colossal. Bottles of £7 wine being sold for £40 plus service. You're unlikely I get anything good wine to drink for £60. Maybe stick to beer? It's a pity the location is good and that will always drive traffic but one gets the impression no one cares about this place. It's just a business. Next time I'd travel and head to soho or pay less at one of the tapas chains where the prices are more reasonable to go to barrafina where they care about the food and it's delicious.

YhTchDvJ946RvOXLwjCF2A.text: El Pirata has been sitting on my restaurant list for a while, so when I was thinking of a place to grab dinner with a friend who works in Victoria, it was a pretty obvious choice. They don't have a booking system on their website, nor do they use Opentable or Bookatable, which leaves you the options of either booking by phone or by email. At first I called and found it relatively easy to make a reservation, but then I didn't get a confirmation so I also emailed to follow up. When my friend was running late and we had to move the reservation back by half an hour with just a few hours' notice, they were also very accommodating. All in all, quite painless to get a table. When I arrived, I was seated immediately in the downstairs part of the restaurant.The other thing I loved about this place is that they have set menus! We really just wanted to catch up and talk, and it was great to not have to spend time agonizing over the options and instead go with one of the two set menus. They are also incredible value, for either £18 or £22 / person.  We went with the £22 option, and we got three courses of tapas - first bread / aioli and a round of cold tapas, like parma ham and some stuffed peppers. We then had fried fish and calamari, prawns, and some chicken wings. Finally we had large servings of lamb, steak, and Spanish omelette.  All the food was fantastic, but my favourites were the lamp chops, the calamari, and the prawns. Everything was delicious and we were both incredibly full at the end.As for the drawbacks, service was not fantastic as I had to ask a number of times for water and for the bill before I managed to get either. The table for 2 is a bit small to fit 3 plates of tapas at a time. But overall, I thought El Pirata was great value and I would definitely recommend it for excellent tapas without a wait! (Here's looking at you, Brindisa...)

17t8BPazepIzy_gN7n07bQ.text: Just had an excellent meal at El Pirata tonight.  We ordered a selection of tapas and a bottle of red wine and had a grand time. Service is a bit ad hoc - not all that bad but more attention can be paid so diners would not have to attempt to pour their water or wine by themselves. Just a thought/observation. We were perfectly equipped to serve ourselves and I liked all of the waiters. The tapas was fresh and well-executed. The tortilla was moist and light. The patatas bravas was also flavorful, even though we were originally dubious about the shade of the sauce. My favorite dish was the baby eels (which we ordered due to a Yelp review recommendation) and E liked the tortilla best. The croquettes jamon iberico were yummy but showed up at our table at the end so we were already quite full. It didn't stop us from ordering the platanos fritos (fried bananas) for desert. See photo. So good.If I'm in the vicinity again, I would definitely go back. Not pretentious at all nor crazy expensive and great tapas. * written in collaboration with E

photos.caption: Photo of El Pirata - Mayfair, London, United Kingdom. Dessert - fried bananas!
Photo of El Pirata - Mayfair, London, United Kingdom. Croquette jamon iberico
Photo of El Pirata - Mayfair, London, United Kingdom. Tortilla, arroz con pollo, patatas bravas, kidneys

YitpkZ525DtxdqIwaCY_1A.text: Delicious food, so so wait staff.The food:I got the steak with manchego cheese. Yes. Perfection. 10000% recommend.The coworkers got the fixed tapas menu #1. I got to try several of the dishes and was very impressed with everything I tried.We sat in the lower part of the restaurant - the wait staff ignored us for awhile until I tried to flag them down. No free refills on soda (but this might be more of an American thing).Got a little loud and dark in the downstairs, I saw people using their cell phones as lights so they could read the menu !! LOLBut highly recommend, definitely worth going to.

DmV7vn4jyTnw0eYMZUv2kA.text: Each of the past 3 years after hiking the famous 500mi pilgrimage El Camino de Santiago in Spain I celebrate with a trip to London and El Pirata. On each occasion the dishes are similar to those I enjoyed in Spain  and I give them an A+.  The service however I'd give a D- I was basically ignored throughout the meal on each occasion and received terribly slow service. So yesterday, unfortunately, was the last time I will return to this hot spot in London. Looks like Bilbao Berria next to the Sofitel might be a new London hotspot to try next.

photos.caption: Photo of El Pirata - Mayfair, London, United Kingdom

449Sc3guhISCGtqSay3sdg.text: Ok this place is well above their Yelp rating... I'm a tough critic especially for Spanish food so it looks like some competitors are trying to bring this place down. I don't think it's someone though the place is packed and I've noticed that a few people here are regulars. I'd recommend the toasted bread with tomatoes to start. Enjoy it

RnSzrLKmkHNaMBM0_-7-DA.text: I've been here a few times over the years and it never disappoints.The food is some of the best tapas in London.  The service is great - very attentive, but not in your face.  The wine list offers a great range of choice!Would recommend either sitting upstairs at a table, the bar or outside.

4ufvSLhN5tubKFSEMtJcZw.text: Four of us enjoyed a wonderful dinner here tonight. We opted for a Set Menu and were very pleased. The food was delicious and plentiful. Our wait staff was outstanding. I would say that the prices were very reasonable in any city but especially so here in this part of London.

DYR2J-KLB3ZSpmygp1hnMw.text: Simply delicious.  We got the set menu for two and everything was excellent.   Save room for the chocolate cake and a glass of red.  Lonely date night place.  Prompt & friendly service

7lQP34RoDMikWhlMprsd2A.text: Really mediocre food, nothing special. Sangria was too sweet for my taste. Spinach salad was ok, but the rest of the food was bland and had too much oil in it :( place is fun though!

photos.caption: Photo of El Pirata - Mayfair, London, United Kingdom. Aroz con pollo

Qjq8N8DttKii5csnfSDc6g.text: Everything was consistently mediocre, even the sangria, which was pretty watered down.  Didn't realize until later that this place advertises on the tourist maps they give out to you at hotels (immediate bad sign!).On the bright side, the server was nice and attentive (though, being 1 of maybe 3 tables in a big dining room doesn't hurt either), and watching the well overindulged May-December couple at the bar provided a nice distraction from the meh food.

photos.caption: Photo of El Pirata - Mayfair, London, United Kingdom. Grilled octopus, tasteless.
